 Eritrea Demobilization and Reintegration Project - Technical Annex 1 A. BACKGROUND AND STRATEGY I. Background to the Conflict 1. Eritrea's struggle for independence began in 1961, following the annexation of Eritrea by Ethiopia, and intensified following the military coup in Ethiopia in 1974. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front (EPLF) gained control of Eritrea in May 1991. Following an internationally supervised referendum, Eritrea gained independence on May 24, 1993. 2. Open conflict between Eritrea and Ethiopia erupted in May 1998, as a consequence of a dispute over their common border in the Badme region. Until May 2000, the fighting was restricted to a relatively limited area within Eritrea displacing some 270,000 people from the border areas. However, on May 12, 2000, and for five weeks thereafter, the war took on far larger proportions with far more dramatic consequences . On this occasion, Ethiopian troops advanced approximately 100 km deep into Eritrean territory, causing an even more dramatic humanitarian crisis as well as widespread destruction of physical infrastructure. 3. The two countries agreed to a Cessation of Hostilities on June 18, 2000, and signed a comprehensive Peace Accord on December 12, 2000. The agreement called for the withdrawal of the Ethiopian army from Eritrean territory and the deployment of a UN peacekeeping force along a 25 kilometer-wide Temporary Security Zone (TSZ) between the two countries until the border is demarcated by a neutral Boundary Commission. The UN Security Council authorized the establishment of a United Nations Mission in Ethiopia and Eritrea (UNMEE) in July 2000, and a peacekeeping force of up to 4,200 in September 2000. The peacekeeping force was fully deployed by March 2001. UNMEE announced the formal establishment of the TSZ on April 18, 2001, following the redeployment of Eritrean forces to the northern boundary of the TSZ. The establishment of the TSZ allows for the restoration of civil administration and the return of internally displaced persons (IDPs) to the areas of the TSZ. II. Humanitarian Impact 47 The escalation of fighting in May 2000 had a severe humanitarian impact. The most dranatic consequence was the sudden displacement of approximately 1.1 million people. This represented 70 % of the population of the Gash Barka and Debub regions, which host 47 percent of the total Eritrean population and contribute 70 percent of its total grain production. An estimated 75,000 Eritreans and Ethiopians of Eritrean origin have also been forcibly deported from Ethiopia. 5. The war has had a severely detrimental impact on local food production capacity, and the Government of Eritrea (GOE)JUN needs assessment undertaken at the end of 2000 determined that 1.76 million rural people would require varying levels of food aid during 2001. This negative impact of the war on the country's food security has been further compounded by drought. Some 738,000 people in Eritrea are estimated to have been affected by drought, many of whom had also been directly affected by the war. III. Economic Impact 6. Since the armed conflict began in May 1998, Eritrea has suffered substantial economic stress. The direct war damage; humanitarian needs for the internally displaced; mobilization of some 200,000 men and women; increases in military spending; drought; decline in private sector activity and loss of port revenues, have all combined to depress the economy. Having averaged 7

Inflation averaged 3.7 percent in 1997 and rose to 19.9 percent in 2000. The budget deficit increased to 48.1 percent of GDP in 2000 from 5.6 percent in 1997. The war has threatened Eritrea's efforts to reduce poverty. With a per capita income among the lowest in Africa (US$200), Eritrea is one of the poorest countries in the world. Furthermore, most of the country's social indicators, such as average life expectancy (51 years) and infant mortality (135 per 1,000 live births), tend to be lower than the averages for Sub-Saharan Africa. 7. The mobilization and maintenance of the troops enlisted for the war contributed significantly to the fiscal stress. The maintenance costs with regards to the wage bill (not including individual food and household allowances) are estimated to average US$60 million per year. These expenditures are a significant drain on the national budget. Furthermore, the absence of a significant proportion of the labor force from active economic life has impacted the economy negatively. Many government offices and public and private enterprises have come close to a standstill over the last two years because a large part of the manpower, including staff in key positions, is still mobilized. 8. Following the signing of the Cessation of Hostilities agreement in June 2000, the immediate priorities were to find the fiscal space to finance rehabilitation expenditures and to stabilize the economy. Critical measures to achieve these goals are reductions in military expenditure and mobilization of donor aid. Substantial inflows of donor aid for humanitarian relief and for rehabilitation have, so far, met the most imnediate needs. 9. Preliminary estimates for 2001 suggest that there has been good progress in stabilizing the economy through the first quarter of 2001. Inflation fell from 26.8 percent at the end of 2000, to 7.7 percent by end 2001 thanks to tight fiscal policy that limited recourse to domestic bank financing of the deficit. The budget deficit fell from 48.1 percent of GDP for 2000 to 32.7 percent of GDP in 2001. IV. Govermnent Response 10. The Government and the people of Eritrea immediately reacted to the humanitarian crisis on two fronts: (i) by providing emergency relief and assistance to the IDPs and the host communities; and (ii) by organizing the available human and financial resources to start rehabilitating the areas damaged by the recent invasion. GOE also appealed for foreign humanitarian and reconstruction assistance in response to the crisis that evolved as a result of the war. 11. In November 2000, following the deployment of the UNMEE peacekeeping force and prompted by significant progress in the peace process, GOE announced its intention to launch a demobilization and reintegration program, building on the previous GOE program, international experiences and best practice. In November 2000, GOE requested the Bank to provide technical assistance in the preparation of a comprehensive demobilization and reintegration program in collaboration with UNDP and other development partners. GOE plans to reduce its army by two thirds and demobilize 200,000 troops within a two-year time frame. The troops to be demobilized consist of remobilized ex-soldiers, people serving in the mandatory National Service program, and soldiers from the regular armed forces. To lead this effort, GOE established a National Commission for the Demobilization and Reintegration Program (NCDRP) by proclamation on April 10, 2001.

Since the outbreak of hostilities in May 1998, most donors have responded favorably to the different humanitarian appeals put out by the Government. A consolidated appeal to seek international support for emergency and relief needs was launched by ERREC in collaboration with the UN in February 2001, for US$132 million. 13. Following the signing of the Cessation of Hostilities Agreement on June 18, 2000, most donors have resumed development activities in Eritrea. In support of the GOE's overriding objectives of rebuilding the economy and restoring social services, the Bank helped GOE prepare and coordinate a US$288 million multi-donor Emergency Reconstruction Program (ERP). This ERP is to assist Eritrea rebuild its physical and social infrastructure, help displaced and drought- affected people resume economic activities and rebuild their lives, and assist GOE to procure essential imports through balance of payments (BOP) support. In addition to an IDA credit of US$90 mnillion, which was approved in November 2000, ERP is financed by the European Union, Italy, Denmark, France, the African Development Bank, and GOE. This is complemented by a US$16 million United Nations Development Program (UNDP)/GOE emergency and rehabilitation program, financed by the Italian Government, and several non-governmental organization (NGO)-assisted projects. The 2001 UN Consolidated Inter-Agency Appeal for Eritrea was launched in January 2001 with the aim of raising US$133.2 million for support of activities, such as food security, voluntary repatriation and reintegration, health and nutrition, family shelter and household items, mine action, water supply and environmental sanitation, and education. By July 25, 2001, 40 percent of the requirement was raised. 14. UNDP provided critical support through an exploratory mission on demobilization and reintegration of soldiers in October 2000, and a small preparatory project to support the GOE planning process. B. BANK RESPONSE AND STRATEGY 1. The Elements of Bank Response 15. From the outbreak of hostilities in May 1998 to the signing of the cessation of hostilities agreement in June 2000, no new lending operations were approved for Eritrea. However, the Bank maintained its ongoing portfolio and continued with the preparation of new projects for presentation to the Board once the time would be appropriate. The focus would be on urgent, high-impact operations, which would have large benefits for the poor and an unquestionable developmental impact. 16. During the last outbreak of hostilities and the unfolding of the humanitarian crisis, the Bank received a request from the GOE for emergency assistance. With the signing of the Cessation of Hostilities, the Bank reallocated a total of US$24.9 million from other ongoing IDA projects in Eritrea to emergency support (essential drugs and other urgently needed medical supplies; water supply and sanitation subprojects in areas with high concentrations of IDPs; nutritional supplements, kitchen utensils, stoves, agricultural inputs, and associated transport services). In July 2000, the Board approved the Eritrea Early Childhood Development Project (US$40 million), the first new lending operation in two years. In addition to the US$90 million credit for ERP, which was approved in November 2000, the Bank has also formulated the HIV/AIDS, Malaria, STDs & TB Control Project (HAMSET), which was approved in December

Upon invitation by GOE, an IDA identification mission visited Eritrea in December 2000. The Government, the IDA mission and the international donor community reached consensus that a demobilization and reintegration program was crucial for the social and economic recovery of Eritrea, and that a comprehensive approach to the Emergency Demobilization and Reintegration Program was essential. Following the signing of the Peace Accord on December 12, 2000, GOE requested the international donor community to launch a multi-donor assessment rission in January 2001 to prepare the Emergency Demobilization and Reintegration Program (EDRP) This was jointly organized by the Bank and UNDP. The mission provided technical assistance to GOE for the main components of the program, and prepared a comprehensive EDRP framework proposal with detailed technical notes. A Post-Conflict Fund grant of US$973,000 was approved by the Bank in January 2001, to assist the GOE set up its institutional structure and make technical preparations. II. Rationale for Bank Involvement 18. The demobilization of Eritrean soldiers is a crucial element of the ongoing peace process. GOE will be able to reinforce its commnitment to the peace process through the effective preparation and implementation of the project. Failure by Eritrea to demobilize a sizeable portion of its armed forces could jeopardize the peace process. In order to grasp the opportunity that the potential peace dividend presents, the Government has given high priority to the objectives of the EDRP and to integrating demobilized soldiers into sustainable productive activities. 19. As a precursor to a more detailed Transitional Support Strategy (TSS), the Bank finalized an Interim Support Strategy (ISS) for Eritrea in November 2000. The ISS outlines the Bank's assistance strategy to the Government in the transition to peace over the next 12-18 months. It also identified the two immediate priorities: demobilization and support to macroeconomic management. A major precept of the ISS was the GOE's recognition of the fact that demobilization was crucial to achieving macroeconomic and fiscal balance. 20. The conflict with Ethiopia led to the diversion of scarce resources from potentially productive (agriculture, industry and basic social services) to non-productive (military) sectors. The EDRP is expected to facilitate the reallocation of public resources from military expenditures to productive and social investments. The demobilization will also alleviate manpower constraints faced by the government and private businesses, and thus contribute to a resumption of critical economic activity. The reduction of military spending will furthermore help ease the fiscal deficit, and is thus crucial to achieving macroeconomic and fiscal balance in the longer term. III. Lessons Learned 21. The preparation and implementation of the Eritrea EDRP builds on international best practices concerning demobilization and reintegration and on Eritrea's own experience with such projects. Some important lessons learned from international experience (Cambodia, Chad, Djibouti, Ethiopia, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, and Uganda) include: (i) the full transition from demobilization to reinsertion and reintegration needs to be supported in order to achieve primary objectives; (ii) to facilitate sustainable reintegration, it is crucial to provide a short-term social safety net to demobilized soldiers (i.e. reinsertion assistance); (iii) information and referral systems can play an important role in linking demobilized soldiers to existing employment opportunities; (iv) duplication of implementation structures should be

Some important lessons learned from previous experience in Eritrea include: (i) despite their rural background most of the ex-soldiers (80 percent) ended up in urban areas in search of training or jobs; (ii) although 89 percent of the ex-soldiers aimed at upgrading their education, only some 15 percent managed to do so; (iii) many ex-soldiers faced difficulties handling the credit they had received; and (iv) the reintegration project component suffered from a lack of funds and experienced staff. Additional lessons learned that have guided the design of the EDRP include: * A socio-economic profile of the demobilized soldiers must be undertaken in the early planning stages, so that projects and services are responding to the specific needs and characteristics of those being demobilized. Important sub-groups should be analyzed separately and in detail (such as disabled, women, younger demobilized, i.e. under 25); * More attention should be paid to the psycho-social needs and support services for the demobilized soldiers and their families than was provided in the previous Demobilization and Reintegration Project in Eritrea; * Reintegration projects implemented at the community level should be inclusive, providing support for IDPs and other war-affected populations, as well as demobilized soldiers; * Follow-up and monitoring capacity is necessary to ensure that the projects supporting reintegration can respond to the evolving and newly identified needs of the demobilized soldiers, their families and communities; and * EDRP projects should be implemented, as much as possible, by line ministries and existing projects or organizations, so as not to create parallel structures and implementation arrangements. Capacity building to expand the delivery capabilities should be an important component of the EDRP and will contribute to longer-term economic recovery initiatives. C. DETAILED PROGRAM DESCRIPTION I. Project Components 30. The EDRP will comprise three main components: (a) demobilization, (b) reinsertion (TSNs), and (c) social and economic reintegration. (a) Demobilization (Estimated Total Costs: US$9.3 million) 31. The objective of the demobilization component is to reduce the number of military personnel by approximately 200,000 over an 18-24 month period. This component of the project will be carried out in three phases of 60-70,000 soldiers. The recently created Demobilization Task Force (DTF) within the Ministry of Defense (MOD) has already started detailed planning. The MOD and the National Commission will carry out a pilot demobilization of approximately 5,000 soldiers to test all procedures and processes. 32. Demobilization Criteria. The definition of demobilization criteria is the critical first step in the planning process. Phase I demobilization will cover special target groups (female, disabled, over-aged and econornically essential soldiers) as well as soldiers of the general group (national service, remobilized ex-soldiers, etc.). The inclusion of the latter group is essential to create and strengthen the public and private sector capacities for reintegrating demobilized soldiers, as well as for general reconstruction. The MOD will establish the criteria such that they are transparent and clear and simplify the selection of soldiers for demobilization. Once the criteria have been established, the DTF will identify the soldiers to be demobilized under the pilot phase and the first phase of demobilization. 33. Logistics Plan. Logistics will be undertaken in three steps. First, soldiers will return their military equipment (weapon, ammunition, clothes, etc.) at their duty station. Second, soldiers will be transported to discharge centers. Third, demobilized soldiers will be transported to their zoba of settlement. The DTF will prepare a logistics plan to ensure the smooth processing of the caseload during these three steps. Special provisions will be made for severely disabled soldiers who may be demobilized directly from the medical facilities. The discharge process itself will be as short as possible and will be limited to approximately one week.
 Eritrea Demobilization and Reintegration Project - Technical Annex 9 34. Information. Soldiers will be informed in advance of their pending demobilization to help them make the necessary personal arrangements both at the duty station and in the community of planned settlement. This information will include the approximate date and planned procedures of discharge, the availability of an appeals mechanism, a basic overview of the EDRP, and an initial preparation for the return to civilian life. Every effort will be made to avoid unrealistic expectations regarding the project. 35. Appeals Mechanism. Soldiers will be given an opportunity to appeal to a decision regarding demobilization. Transparent criteria for demobilization are essential to this end, allowing a soldier to assess whether or not s/he indeed meets the criteria for demobilization. An independent appeals mechanism will be set up within the Ministry of Defense to this end. Soldiers selected for demobilization as well as those not selected will have the right to appeal to the decision of the MOD. 36. Socioeconomic Data. While still at their duty stations, the DTF will collect socioeconomic data on all soldiers slated for demobilization. This information will be linked to the demobilization database and represent the baseline information for project purposes. A non- transferable identification system will be required to ensure that only eligible demobilized soldiers have access to benefits. A system of military and civilian ID cards is already well established in the country. However, the requirements in terms of caseload and time are such that a new, digital system will need to be employed to produce durable ID cards. 37. Discharge Process. Given the magnitude of each phase, the discharge process poses a particular implementation challenge. Discharge teams will be identified comprising both military and civilian members in order to cover all aspects of the demobilization. The latter will be carried out in specially prepared discharge centers. Existing facilities, whether military or civilian, will serve as discharge centers. The discharge centers will be prepared to process a large caseload within a short-time period. The discharge teams will assess the needs in terms of lodging, food, health services, sanitation, etc. Separate facilities (lodging, sanitation, health services) will be prepared for female soldiers. In addition, special facilities may be required for disabled veterans, especially regarding accessibility. The "discharge chain" will comprise several steps, whose sequence will be determined prior to the preparation of the discharge centers: * Arrival. Upon arrival at the discharge center, soldiers will be provided with basic goods (soap, blanket, towel, etc.) for their short stay in the center. * Identification. The identity of each soldier will be verified using the soldier's military ID card. The ID number will be compared with the computerized list of soldiers to be demobilized. * Discharge Formalities. The exchange of a soldier's military ID card for his/her new civilian project ID and discharge certificate symbolizes the termination of his/her military service. As of this moment, an individual will turn into a "demobilized soldier" and will be under the authority of the NCDRP. * Pre-discharge Orientation. Pre-discharge orientation (counseling) will provide demobilized soldiers with critical information about project benefits, implementation arrangements at the central and zoba level, reintegration opportunities, health issues (including HIV/AIDS, reproductive health, etc.), civic rights and duties (including women's legal rights), etc. The orientation project will be organized in modules and will be carried out by a mixed group of mnilitary/civilian staff. The DTF and the Secretariat will identify counselors, who will undergo training. Special modules will be offered for
 Eritrea Demobilization and Reintegration Project - Technical Annex 10 female and disabled ex-soldiers targeting their special reintegration needs. Special materials will be prepared for counseling and distribution (booklets, job guides, etc.). Again, every effort will be made to avoid the creation of unrealistic expectations about project benefits. * Medical Screening. A special medical team will screen demobilized soldiers to identify serious diseases or impairments that may affect his/her ability to enjoy economnic and social reintegration (cough, chronic diarrhea, symptoms of sexually transmitted diseases, alcohol and drug consumption, symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder, etc.). Furthermore, voluntary counseling and testing (VCT) for HV/AIDS will be offered. To this end, medical teams will be established and will comprise members from the respective military and civilian authorities. * Transport to the Community of Settlement. The Secretariat will organize transport from the discharge centers to the zoba level using public or private transport providers. For continuation to the cormmunity of settlement, ex-soldiers will receive a transport allowance as part of the TSN. 38. Pilot demobilization. The MOD and the National Commission will carry out a pilot demobilization of approximately 5,000 soldiers to test all procedures and processes. This pilot will target general profile soldiers as well as special target groups. The lessons from the pilot operation will be assessed and incorporated into program design before phase I demobilization commences. 39. Phase I demobilization. In order to manage the caseload of 60-70,000 soldiers and to maximize the use of the discharge teams and centers, phase I demobilization will be undertaken in batches over a period of 3-6 months. Each batch will comprise approximately 5,000 soldiers, to be demobilized simultaneously from approximately 10 discharge centers (throughput of 500 soldiers per week per center). (b) Reinsertion (Estimated Total Costs: US$120 million) 40. Transitional Safety Nets. Upon discharge, a demobilized soldier loses his/her source of income and is normally in a critical financial situation until s/he can generate income through (self)-employment. During this period (the reinsertion phase), a demobilized soldier is in need of special assistance or a Transitional Safety Net allowance (TSN) to cover his/her personal or family's basic material needs. TSN is the cash equivalent of a defined basket of basic goods and services enabling the beneficiary family unit to re-establish a civilian household. The basket consists of basic goods such as household items, clothing and cooking utensils and makes provision for children's education. As part of the TSN, the World Food Program has agreed with Government to provide up to 12 months of supplementary food support to vulnerable demobilized soldiers. 41. The TSN will consist of two components: (i) Basic transition support: The first component of the TSN will be a standard allowance to which all demobilized soldiers are entitled. The basic transition support will, on average, amount to US$600 per soldier. The $600 unit cost includes the in-kind contribution to the reinsertion package by the World Food Program, which is valued at US$75. Therefore, the cash contribution to the average reinsertion package that IDA and the Multi Donor Trust Fund would finance would be US$525. The total estimated costs for reinsertion amount to US$120 million (200,000 * US$600). The total cost for the in-kind
 Eritrea Demobilization and Reintegration Project - Technical Annex 11 contribution amounts to US$15 million and the total cost for the cash contribution amounts to US$105 million. It was agreed with GOE that the basic transition support would be differentiated into three or four broad categories based on rank and length of service. Government prepared the criteria for this differentiation prior to Negotiations with IDA. It was also agreed that the resource envelope for the basic transition support, however, would not exceed US$120 million. (ii) Enhanced support to vulnerable groups: The second component of the TSN will be made available to some demobilized soldiers based on relative vulnerabilities as indicated by their health status. Health status covers demobilized soldiers with severe or moderate disability and those with severe chronic illness. A medical commission of the MOD will determine eligibility for enhanced support according to pre-determined and transparent criteria. Payments will be effected in various installments. The enhanced support to vulnerable groups will be paid in installments covering three months each. TSN-payment procedures. Payments will be effected through the banking system with demobilized soldiers being paid in their zobas of settlement. A managing bank will be selected on the basis of cost and representation in the zobas.  Eritrea Demobilization and Reintegration Project - Technical Annex 12 (c) Social and Economic Reintegration (Estimated Total Costs: US$50 million) 45. The social and economic reintegration of demobilized soldiers occurs over time. The principal protagonist and the active initiator of the process is the individual demobilized soldier. Support for economic and social reintegration may ease the process, but successful reintegration is dependent upon a dynamic interaction of social, economic and political factors with the returning demobilized soldiers. Family ties, community support, and economic circumstances and opportunities play a critical role, and are taken into account in the design of the reintegration support project. The design of the social and economic reintegration support projects is based on the following principles: (i) Opportunities. Reintegration projects are opportunities that the ex-soldiers choose to access, unlike the reinsertion support (TSN), which is an entitlement. Some of these opportunities may be designed in direct response to the needs and socio-economnic characteristics of the ex-soldiers. Others may be services or projects provided by a range of governmental entities, NGOs, banking institutions or private enterprises to the ex- soldiers as members of the society at-large. In the case of disabled demobilized soldiers, family members can substitute for demobilized soldiers, thereby protecting household economic self-sufficiency. (ii) Inclusive Reintegration Supports. The EDRP is designed to be an integral part of the broader post-war economic recovery process. Therefore, it is not only permissible but also desirable that, internally displaced, returnees, deportees and other war-affected persons be included in local level projects under the EDRP to promote community cohesion and economic recovery. However, at least 50% of the program participants should be demobilized soldiers. The EDRP, especially in the regions of Gash-Barka and Debub, will coordinate closely with projects supporting the return and reintegration of other target groups so that the assistance is compatible and mutually supportive. While the EDRP reintegration assistance will be inclusive rather than exclusively provided to ex-soldiers, some assistance may be specifically targeted at the demobilized soldiers. The needs of female demobilized soldiers and the spouses of returning male soldiers are likely to require particular attention. (iii) Capacity Builiding. The lack of human resource and institutional capacity is a major obstacle in all sectors to the expanded delivery of services and projects supporting the reintegration of the demobilized soldiers. Therefore, each component initially needs to implement targeted capacity building measures. These measures do not substitute for longer-term human resource development and capacity building projects being undertaken by the Eritrean Government with the support of various donors. Rather, they are designed to unblock specific implementation bottlenecks in the proposed projects, while complementing long-term ongoing projects. 46. Implementation through NCDRP (US$35 million). Activities under the social and economic reintegration component will initially be coordinated and financed through the NCDRP. These activities will largely be implemented and/or technically supervised by line ministries (e.g. Agriculture, Education, Fisheries, Labor, Local Government, Public Works, etc.) in accordance with standards and guidelines applied for Bank assistance. Where feasible, the NCDRP will finance the participation of demobilized soldiers and other war-affected populations in existing programs. Where assistance to reintegration sub-projects cannot be channeled through existing programs, the NCDRP will coordinate closely with line Ministries to ensure that the implementation of these activities will fall within Government's medium and longer-term sector strategies and policies.

Reintegration activities are increasingly expected to be financed directly through targeted components in existing or forthcoming GOE sector programs, such as the Education Sector Program (skills development and training), Community Development Program (micro-credit), the Emergency Reconstruction Program ('cash for work', rehabilitation of social/economic infrastructure), the Roads Sector Program (public works), the Agriculture Sector Program (rural development activities) and HAMSET (EIV-AIDS counseling). These sector operations will be scaled up to absorb the demobilized soldiers and other war-affected populations. It was agreed that the absorption of these target populations would have to be formalized in the project and legal documentation. GOE and IDA agreed to channel US$5 million and US$2 million of the proposed EDRP reintegration funds through the respective Community Development Program (CDP) structures: i.e. the Micro Credit and Savings Scheme and the Micro Business Advisory Services scheme. Since some of these sector operations will only become operational in FY03 and FY04, the NCDRP will retain a level of financial and human resources sufficient to address the social and economic reintegration needs of the initial batches of soldiers to be demobilized. 48. Special Target Groups. The EDRP is placing special focus on three sub-groupings of demobilized soldiers: female soldiers; those who have been disabled as a result of the war; and HIV positive soldiers. A premise is that all three groups, and especially female ex-soldiers, have strengths and experiences that will help facilitate their reintegration into mainstream social and economic life. They will be encouraged and supported to pursue existing opportunities and programs, and will be covered by the counseling activities under the program. The EDRP also recognizes, however, the need for special support for the especially vulnerable through the extra reinsertion payment, as well as enhanced reintegration assistance. Disabled soldiers. As the reintegration phase is opportunity rather than entitlement driven, disabled ex-soldiers will be encouraged and supported to access existing programs. A special needs assessment is required to determine capacity for further education, skills training and employment. In addition, some disabled will need additional entitlements, according to their degree of disability based on needs assessment and earlier screening. 51. Disabled soldiers will be assisted to access mainstream economic reintegration activities such as business advice and training, credit schemes, employment and wage subsidy schemes, agricultural support, and access to land. Some groups of disabled will need specific training to be able to pursue certain employment opportunities. While community-based rehabilitation could become an important support for the integration of disabled soldiers, the capacity of the existing Community-Based Rehabilitation (CBR) Program will need substantive strengthening to be able to meet the new challenge. 52. Soldiers and HIV/AIDS. Based on the assumption that military personnel is a high-risk group for HIV/AIDS, EDRP will be cooperating closely with the HAMSET project to implement

Targeting of women soldiers and male soldiers' widows and spouses will take into account the diverse vulnerabilities and capacities of women. Certain program components will primarily enhance women's social, economic and political empowerment. 56. With these considerations in mind, the EDRP takes a threefold approach to gender: * Full integration of women in all program components. This means that provisions will be designed and implemented so that female demobilized soldiers can have full access and participation in all opportunities supported by the EDRP. * Given the history of (partial) exclusion of Eritrean women from many economic and social aspects of life, program components will contain accompanying measures (advocacy, sensitization) to encourage female participation and acceptance in the work force. The objectives of this component are to facilitate the smooth reintegration of demobilized soldiers into their communities, and contribute to continued social cohesion in the communities and in the society at large. The Eritrean economy is seriously constrained by the lack of skilled manpower. Many demobilized soldiers are likely to encounter significant difficulty entering the shattered economy that has little absorptive capacity, particularly in the medium and large-scale formal sector. The reconstruction of the country and the regeneration (and growth) of the economy will require a training system that complements development imperatives, is market responsive and stimulates increased production and enterprise, particularly in the micro and small sector. An estimated US$15 million will be spent on skills development and training. 67. The public and private technical education and vocational training (TEVT) system currently operates below the quantitative and qualitative capacity required to provide the demobilized soldiers with appropriate skills for formal and informal employment. The TEVT system suffers from a lack of qualified instructors, insufficient and inappropriate equipment, shortages of training consumables and technical textbooks, outdated curriculum, and the absence of a national system of skills assessment and certification. Training and skills development, are nonetheless, crucial to the process of facilitating the economic reintegration of demobilized soldiers. The public and private training system will thus need to increase its capacity whilst being responsive to the market. D. INSTITUTIONAL ARRANGEMENTS AND PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION I. Institutional Arrangements 78. The NCDRP has developed an Operational Manual (OM), which has legal authority by virtue of the Proclamation #113/2001 establishing the NCDRP and as a covenant to the Development Credit Agreement. 79. This OM describes NCDRP' s institutional set-up (see Attachment I) and reflects procedures on decision-making in terms of sub-project identification, appraisal, approval, implementation and progress monitoring, including procurement, financial and administrative management procedures acceptable to the World Bank. Project management is being given larger decision-making authority within specifically described procedures and eligibility criteria. In the case of the Eritrea Demobilization and Reintegration Program, the objectives of this approach are to achieve a wider variety of service delivery which corresponds better to local conditions and which responds more to the local needs of the demobilized soldiers and their families and communities. 80. Demobilization will be carried out directly by the Secretariat in close coordination with the DTF of the MOD. The payment of reinsertion benefits will be done through the banking system. The second and third payment against the positive list of imports will be made when the Borrower furnishes to IDA evidence in form and substance satisfactory to IDA: (i) consisting of a list of demobilized soldiers identifying the amount of funds payable to the Demobilized Soldiers under the Demobilization and Reintegration Program; and (ii) showing that a random sample of at least 2% of the number of demobilized soldiers on the list furnished to IDA have (A) in accordance with the said list received the amounts payable to them, and (B) acquired the goods and services intended for them under the Program. Program Sustainability 107. The program is designed to support the sustainable reintegration of demobilized soldiers into mainstream social and economic life. The return to productive life by a significant proportion of the country's labor force and the public savings incurred by reducing the armed forces are expected to contribute in a major way to a sustainable post-conflict recovery and the development process. VII. Benefits 109. The proposed project is designed to provide Government access to an adequate level of financing to demobilize 60,000 soldiers and promote social and economic recovery following the border conflict with Ethiopia. The major immediate benefits are: (i) to assist the demobilized soldiers to rebuild their livelihoods and resume productive economic activities; (ii) to reverse the general slowdown of social and economic development due to the conflict and the diversion of human resources into the military; and (iii) to contribute to economic recovery and fiscal stability through reallocation of public resources from military to social and economic investments. VIII. Risks 110. External Risks. In case of a resumption of hostilities, the Bank would consider exercising its remedies under the legal agreement. Even if the conflict does not resume, delays in the peace process might result in delays in the implementation of the second and third phase of the Project. However, the signing of the peace agreement by both parties to the conflict, the full deployment of the UN peacekeeping force (UNMEE), and the recent acceptance of the Boundary Commission's verdict reduce this risk. Suspension of new assistance because of continued concerns regarding governance might jeopardize the financing of phases two and three. However, in the context of the above positive developments it is likely that the Demobilization and Reintegration Program remains a priority for Government and donor partners.

 9. Entity/Project-Specific. A new entity, the National Commission for the Demobilization and Reintegration Program has been established for the sole purpose of managing the implementation of the program. The establishment of a semi-autonomous institution made up of experienced professionals is a sign of commitment on the part of the Government to remove, as far as possible, any impediments to the smooth implementation of the program. The use of a project-specific financial management and accounting system will also address the weak financial management and accounting environment currently found in the public sector. 10. Implementing Entity. The challenges facing the new entity will be the lack of experience in implementing Bank-financed projects. However, management is assembling a team of competent staff, a number of whom have prior experience in implementing donor funded projects. This use of a semi-autonomous institution with qualified and experienced professionals to manage the accounting and auditing arrangements will ensure that this risk will be mitigated once the right professionals are in place. The SCMP is familiar with Bank procedures from implementing the savings and credit scheme under the Bank financed ECDF. 11. Funds Flow. The program will use a quick disbursement mechanism, consisting of disbursements in foreign exchange for purchases based on a positive list of imports. The local currency proceeds from the sale of this foreign exchange will thereafter be deposited into a Demobilization and Reintegration Fund Account to be utilized for the Program. The Funds disbursed under this mechanism will amount to US$30 million equivalent. Other funding mechanisms consist of three Special Accounts with the Bank of Eritrea (BE) in United States Dollars to which the proceeds from the FDA Credit will be deposited; and related accounts in local currency with a commercial bank to which draw downs from the Special Account will be credited for program financing and administrative expenses; and an account in local currency with a commercial bank to which counterpart funding by the Government will be deposited in respect of any expenditure of the EDRP that may be provided for in the Development Credit Agreement. 12. Flow of funds to the Regional Offices and other implementing agencies will be very minimal especially in the early stages of the implementation of the program. Payments for the TSN and the Reinsertion component will use the banking system in the country to pay directly the demobilized soldiers in their areas of settlement. While procurement arrangements will be initiated from the community level, the Secretariat will, as far as possible, manage the required expenditures from the head office, including international procurement. 13. Staffing. A Finance and Administration Manager (FAM), with requisite qualifications and relevant experience, has been appointed in order to direct and guide the financial management operations of the EDRP. Additional qualified and experienced accounting, administrative and support staff will be required to assist the Finance and Administration Manager. The levels and numbers of such staff will be determined as a matter of urgency. Varying levels of training will be required in financial management and government accounting; information systems and computer applications; and procedures relating to use of funds. Adequate staffing arrangements for the SCMP are already in place. 14. Accounting Policies and Procedures. The FM will document the internal processing procedures and controls for the EDRP in a Financial Procedures Manual. 15. Internal Audit. An Internal Audit function will be established in the EDRP Secretariat. This will be used as an independent appraisal function to examine and evaluate activities of the 37
 program. Reporting to the Commissioner, the mission of the Internal Audit will be to support members of the EDRP in the effective discharge of their responsibilities. 16. External Audit. The EDRP will be a Government program and the Office of the Auditor-General is mandated to audit all government programs, irrespective of the sources of funding. In general, the Auditor-General has always sub-contracted this responsibility in respect of donor-funded projects and has indicated his doing so in respect of the EDRP. In due course, therefore, the EDRP Secretariat, in consultation with the Auditor-General and the World Bank and other donors, will appoint independent auditors in compliance with the financial covenants contained in the IDA Credit Agreement. TOR for the external auditor will be modeled on Annex XIX, Financial Accounting Reporting and Auditing Handbook (FARAH) of the World Bank, which contains "Sample Terms of Reference for the Audit of Project Financial Statements (and accompanying SOE and SA where applicable)." 17. The following audit reports will be required to be submitted to the Bank: Audit Report Due Date Project Six months after fiscal year end SOE Six months after fiscal year end Special Account Six months after fiscal year end Management Letter Six months after fiscal year end 18. Reporting and Monitoring. The financial transactions relating to this operation will be recorded and monitored using a project-specific computerized financial management and accounting system. The Finance Manager will determine: (i) EDRP's Chart of Accounts as well as the format and content of quarterly reports and annual financial statements; (ii) the selection and adoption of accounting policies and accounting standards; and (iii) the need to include any supplementary notes to the project financial statements in order to enhance the presentation of a "true and fair view." Subject to a decision being made, these reports will include financial statements (e.g. sources and application of funds; expenditure classified by project components, disbursement categories, expenditure types, and comparison with budgets. 19. Information Systems. The development of a Management Information System will be crucial to the smooth implementation and monitoring of the program. As a result, an Information Technology consultancy will be required to set up the system, including the linkage between financial and other information. 20. Impact on Procurement Arrangements. A procurement assessment has been carried out and concluded that EDRP Secretariat will be capable of handling all procurement requirements at the head office. 21. Disbursement Arrangements. Given that: this is an emergency program with a short project implementation period of three to four years; the use of a transitional institution whose mandate will finish upon completion of the program activities; the fact that 60 percent of the project costs will be disbursed within the first two years of implementation to the approximately 200,000 soldiers to be demobilized; and taking the project characteristics and risks into consideration, agreement has been obtained from the Bank's Loan Department to dispense with the requirement for the project to attain the minimum requirements for PMR-based disbursements. This, therefore means that the traditional disbursement procedures will be followed throughout the implementation period of the program. However, the Secretariat wiUl be 38
 required to prepare Financial Monitoring Reports (FMRs) to track expenditures for the program. 22. Action Plan. Detailed below is an action plan that will ensure that acceptable financial management arrangements will be in place. Action Responsibility Completion date 1 Appointment of Project Finance Manager for the NCDRP Done accounting department in the EDRP Secretariat 2 Preparation of Financial Management Manual describing accounting systems and procedures, internal controls and funds flow processes: First draft NCDRP/IDA Board Final draft incorporating IDA comments review Effectiveness NCDRP 3 Finalization of a Chart of Accounts NCDRP Effectiveness 4 Format and content of monthly/quarterly/annual NCDRP, IDA Effectiveness financial reporting agreed 5 Accounting system installed and running NCDRP Effectiveness 6 Recruitment of an Internal Auditor for the Internal Audit NCDRP Effectiveness function of the EDRP Secretariat 7 Opening Bank Accounts/Preparation initial cash flows NCDRP Effectiveness 8 External Audit arrangements on approved TOR NCDRP Effectiveness 24. Conclusion. Subject to the next issues and action plan presented above being adequately addressed by the Secretariat prior to Effectiveness, the World Bank's minimum financial management requirements will be satisfied. 39

doc.repnme: Eritrea - Emergency Demobilization and Reintegration Project
doc.abstracts: The overall development objectives of the Eritrea's Emergency Demobilization and Reintegration Project are to: 1) demobilize and provide reinsertion support to about 200,000 soldiers in three phases; 2) support the social and economic reintegration of demobilized soldiers, including strengthening of institutional capacities of relevant government and local implementing partners; and 3) support macroeconomic stability. This Credit , constituting the first phase of the Program finances the demobilization of 60,000 soldiers. There are three project components: demobilization, reinsertion support in the form of a transitional safety net (TSN); and social and economic reintegration. Activities under the first component include: assembly; identification; collection of socioeconomic data; pre-discharge orientation; and transport to communities of return. With the second component, demobilized soldiers will receive allowances to cover his/her personal or family's basic material needs. Additional support will be provided to demobilized soldiers with severe or moderate disability and those with severe chronic illness. The third component focuses attention on these vulnerable groups: female soldiers, those who were disabled because of war, and HIV positive soldiers. Activities include information and sensitization, social and economic information and referral services, counseling, and strengthening of social capital. Economic activities are designed to develop financial self-sufficiency
